item.title: Traveling This Week? Here’s What to Know About the Blizzard.
item.content:encoded: A major winter storm brought heavy snow and a long list of delays and cancellations across much of the Northeast.

item.title: Pizzoccheri Was Prominent at Winter Olympics in Italy
item.content:encoded: Pizzoccheri, a hearty buckwheat pasta, graced restaurant menus and the athletes’ cafeterias. A chef hopes it can put a spotlight on the valley where it comes from.

item.title: France Summons U.S. Ambassador Over Comments on Activist’s Killing
item.content:encoded: Charles Kushner, President Trump’s envoy to Paris, was called in after the State Department cited “violent radical leftism” in the beating death of Quentin Deranque, 23.

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Is the Most Patriotic Show on Television
item.content:encoded: An emergency room that’s a mirror.

item.title: BAFTAs 2026: The Best and Worst Moments
item.content:encoded: Alan Cumming forced fishy British snacks onto movie stars. Paddington Bear presented an award. And a racist slur and swearing.

item.title: The Human Cost of the Trump Administration’s War on Science
item.content:encoded: The ripple effects of cutting H.I.V. research funding.

item.title: Supreme Court to Weigh Oil-Industry Effort to End a Major Climate Suit
item.content:encoded: The case could have significant bearing on a range of other lawsuits brought against the fossil fuel industry by cities and states across the country.

item.title: Cities May Be ‘Evolutionary Training Grounds’ For Spotted Lanternflies
item.content:encoded: Living in urban China may have given the insects the traits they needed to thrive in the United States, a new study suggests.

item.title: Backed by Anthropic, a Super PAC Begins an Ad Blitz in Support of A.I. Regulation
item.content:encoded: The ads by Public First Action, which started airing on Monday, are part of an escalating political war over artificial intelligence before the midterm elections.

item.title: Architecture Prize Responds After Tom Pritzker’s Epstein Ties Surface
item.content:encoded: A Pritzker Prize statement cited the award’s independence after Mr. Pritzker, who directs the foundation behind the award, resigned as chairman of the Hyatt Corporation.

item.title: For Iran’s Rulers, Refusing U.S. Demands Is a Risk Worth Taking
item.content:encoded: The government in Tehran sees capitulating to Washington’s demands on uranium enrichment and ballistic missiles as riskier to its survival than going to war, analysts say.

item.title: ‘A.I. Literacy’ Is the New Drivers’ Ed at This Newark School
item.content:encoded: Teachers say they want to equip high school students to drive artificial intelligence, rather than be mere passengers steered by chatbots.

item.title: ‘A.I. Literacy’ Is the New Drivers’ Ed at This Newark School
item.content:encoded: Teachers say they want to equip high school students to drive artificial intelligence, rather than be mere passengers steered by chatbots.

item.title: Top Fed Official Sees Little Effect on Rate Outlook From Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
item.content:encoded: Christopher J. Waller, a Federal Reserve governor, said he would support a pause in rate cuts in March if the labor market continued to show signs of stabilizing.

item.title: Top Fed Official Sees Little Effect on Rate Outlook From Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
item.content:encoded: Christopher J. Waller, a Federal Reserve governor, said he would support a pause in rate cuts in March if the labor market continued to show signs of stabilizing.

item.title: Tariff Turmoil Returns to Global Markets
item.content:encoded: Businesses and U.S. trade partners are again grappling with the uncertainty of President Trump’s trade war, even as he imposes new levies.

item.title: What to Know About the Killing of ‘El Mencho’
item.content:encoded: The Mexican government has killed Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes, the longtime leader of one of Mexico’s most powerful gangs, the Jalisco New Generation Cartel.

item.title: The Next Conflict
item.content:encoded: We’re looking at the potential for a U.S. attack on Iran.

item.title: U.K., Australia and Others Worse Off Under Trump’s New Tariffs
item.content:encoded: Many important U.S. trading partners are facing higher duties after President Trump, reacting to a Supreme Court setback, set the rate on a new set of global tariffs at 15 percent.

item.title: EU Support for Ukraine Stumbles as Hungary Looks to Delay Aid
item.content:encoded: Hungary said that it would block both the latest sanctions package on Russia and a financial aid package to Kyiv worth about $106 billion.

item.title: Killing of Cartel Boss Sets Off Chaos in Mexico, and Trump Has a New Plan for Tariffs
item.content:encoded: Plus, a shooting at Mar-a-Lago.

item.title: Drug Lord ‘El Mencho’ Was Killed in Mexico. What’s Next for the Cartel He Led?
item.content:encoded: The death of Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes dealt a major blow to the Jalisco New Generation Cartel, but few believe it spells the end for the powerful group.

item.title: What’s Happened Since the Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
item.content:encoded: After the Trump administration’s punishing tariffs were invalidated, the president said he would impose new tariffs using a different authority. It’s been a whirlwind.

item.title: What’s Happened Since the Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
item.content:encoded: After the Trump administration’s punishing tariffs were invalidated, the president said he would impose new tariffs using a different authority. It’s been a whirlwind.

item.title: Fact-Check: Trump’s Latest Claims on Jobs, Inflation and Crime
item.content:encoded: Trends on jobs, inflation and crime that began before Donald Trump retook office continued, largely unabated, in his first year back.

item.title: Fact-Check: Trump’s Latest Claims on Jobs, Inflation and Crime
item.content:encoded: Trends on jobs, inflation and crime that began before Donald Trump retook office continued, largely unabated, in his first year back.

item.title: Why the Supreme Court Struck Down Trump’s Tariffs
item.content:encoded: Our reporter Ann E. Marimow describes the rationale of the Supreme Court’s 6-to-3 ruling to strike down President Trump’s sweeping tariffs.

item.title: Judges Grow Angry Over Trump Administration Violating Their Orders
item.content:encoded: At least 35 times since August, federal judges have ordered the administration to explain why it should not be punished for violating their orders in immigration cases.

item.title: Supreme Court Considers Fate of Docks and Other Assets Seized by Cuba in 1960
item.content:encoded: Amid rising tensions with Cuba, the Trump administration is backing lawsuits that would allow Americans to get compensation for property confiscated by Fidel Castro’s regime.

item.title: World’s 50 Best Restaurants Draws Criticism After Choosing to Hold Ceremony in Abu Dhabi
item.content:encoded: The World’s 50 Best Restaurants will give out its awards this year in a country that has been accused of human rights violations.

item.title: Homeownership Is Out of Reach for Many Americans, Despite a Buyer’s Market
item.content:encoded: A growing split between low-to-middle-income families and wealthy households is changing who has access to homeownership now.

item.title: Democrats Consider Breaking a Taboo in Washington State: A Millionaires Tax
item.content:encoded: The state where Jeff Bezos and Bill Gates made fortunes might have progressive social policies, but its resistance to an income tax is similar to conservative states. That might change.

item.title: The Ukrainian Bureaucrat Working to Squeeze Russia’s War Machine
item.content:encoded: Vladyslav Vlasiuk has spent the past four years pressing Western allies to squeeze the Russian economy through more sanctions. He hopes that 2026 will be the tipping point.

item.title: ‘A.I. Literacy’ Is Trending in Schools. Here’s Why.
item.content:encoded: Artificial intelligence companies are urging teachers to prepare students for an “A.I.-driven future.” What that means varies from school to school.

item.title: Need an Outfit? Pickle Clothing Rental App Helps Users Stay on Trend.
item.content:encoded: Pickle, a new peer-to-peer apparel-rental app, helps users stay on trend without having to go into debt or rely on climate-unfriendly fast fashion.

item.title: The Zero Units Fought for the C.I.A. in Afghanistan. In the U.S., They’re Living in Fear.
item.content:encoded: A shooting in Washington, D.C., threw their immigration status into jeopardy — and brought attention to a long-hidden dimension of America’s war.

item.title: From Sundance Director to Head of Film Forum
item.content:encoded: Tabitha Jackson sees an opportunity to develop the next generation of cinephiles at the Greenwich Village art-house cinema.

item.title: As Trump Touts Economic Gains, Many Workers Still Feel the Pinch
item.content:encoded: President Trump says that he has brought down inflation, but families are still struggling to pay bills and plan for the future.

item.title: When Faced With Claims of Racism, Trump Points to His Black Friends
item.content:encoded: President Trump has often invoked his unnamed Black friends, or name-checked celebrities and athletes, when asked to discuss anything related to Black voters.

item.title: Trump Aides Project Confidence on Tariffs After Court Loss
item.content:encoded: Administration officials maintain that they can replicate the sky-high duties recently invalidated by the Supreme Court.

item.title: They Did Deals With Trump to Get Lower Tariffs. Now They Are Stuck.
item.content:encoded: Countries that under the threat of tariffs made commitments like enormous investment pledges face the reality that they might have been better off waiting.

item.title: Trump Considers Targeted Strike Against Iran, Followed by Larger Attack
item.content:encoded: The top negotiators plan to meet in Geneva on Thursday for last-ditch talks, debating a new proposal that could create an off-ramp as two carrier groups massed within striking distance of Iran.

item.title: BAFTAs Winners 2026: ‘One Battle After Another’ Wins Best Film, Besting ‘Sinners’
item.content:encoded: Paul Thomas Anderson’s comedy drama won six awards at the British equivalent of the Oscars. The best actor choice, however, was a surprise.

item.title: Trump Calls on Netflix to Oust Susan Rice From Its Board
item.content:encoded: The president made the attack as Netflix and Paramount Skydance face a key deadline in a bidding war for Warner Bros. Discovery.

item.title: Mixed Signals Churn Stock Market Despite Recent Highs
item.content:encoded: Major indexes have mostly been treading water for months, as investors’ exuberance for artificial intelligence wears off.

item.title: For India, Buying Russian Oil Just Got More Complicated
item.content:encoded: India’s prime minister acceded to many of President Trump’s demands under pressure of heavy tariffs. It would be awkward to reject them now.

item.title: Should I Tell My Housekeeper, ‘I’m Here for You’?
item.content:encoded: Plus, what to do when your job interviewer spouts off on things better left unsaid.

item.title: Trump’s Challenge to Free Market Capitalism
item.content:encoded: Stakes in private companies. Handshake deals with chief executives. The president’s economic policy has drifted far from principles that long defined the Republican Party. Is it capitalism at all?

item.title: Trump’s Challenge to Free Market Capitalism
item.content:encoded: Stakes in private companies. Handshake deals with chief executives. The president’s economic policy has drifted far from principles that long defined the Republican Party. Is it capitalism at all?

item.title: A Roving Reporter on the Future of Transit in New York City
item.content:encoded: “A lot of interesting things happening in the city involve how people get around,” said Stefanos Chen, a Metro reporter and lifelong bus aficionado.

item.title: Inside the Big Tech Lobbying Machine Aiming to Halt Social Media Bans
item.content:encoded: Tech giants, including Meta and Alphabet, are spending lavishly on splashy billboard ads, courting on-the-fence politicians and bulking up their ranks of lobbyists.

item.title: New York Nurses’ Strike Ends After 6 Weeks as Last Holdouts Approve Deal
item.content:encoded: Workers at NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia hospital voted for a contract with raises and layoff protections, meaning more than 4,000 nurses will return.

item.title: Trump Doubles Down on Closing Tax Loophole on Cheap Imports
item.content:encoded: The exemption was shut down last year by President Trump based, in part, on the same legal grounds as the tariffs that were invalidated by the Supreme Court.

item.title: Trump Says He Will Raise Global Tariff to 15 Percent
item.content:encoded: The move signaled that the president would press ahead with steep global import taxes despite the legal setback from the Supreme Court.

item.title: JPMorgan Admits to Debanking Trump After Jan. 6 Capitol Attacks
item.content:encoded: Nation’s largest bank, in response to a lawsuit filed by the president, confirmed his longstanding complaint about “debanking.”

item.title: Trump’s Trade Gamble Will Continue, Despite Supreme Court Rebuke
item.content:encoded: The president seems as intent on tariffs as ever and argues that his trade agenda is succeeding, despite little evidence to support it

item.title: After Tariff Decision, What Happens to Trump’s Deals With China, Canada and Europe?
item.content:encoded: The Supreme Court’s decision to invalidate many of President Trump’s tariffs raised questions about what would become of agreements struck with major U.S. trading partners.

item.title: Businesses Celebrate Tariff Relief, And Brace for New Uncertainty
item.content:encoded: The Supreme Court’s ruling against many of President Trump’s tariffs cheered executives who set to work seeking refunds on their duties.

item.title: Six Questions on the Future of Trump’s Tariffs
item.content:encoded: The Supreme Court’s ruling on the president’s tariffs has jolted Washington and the business world. Here’s what to watch next.

item.title: With Tariff Changes, Consumers May Be Stuck in a Waiting Game
item.content:encoded: Some companies could decide to temper price increases, but the effect would take time to materialize.

item.title: ‘Murky Waters’ for Global Businesses After Trump’s Tariff Loss
item.content:encoded: Even after the Supreme Court invalidated many of the president’s levies, foreign leaders and executives assume that U.S. tariffs are here to stay, in one form or another.

item.title: He Researched Dishonesty. He Got Friendly With Jeffrey Epstein.
item.content:encoded: Dan Ariely, a behavioral scientist at Duke, sought out the convicted sex offender for his research. Their yearslong correspondence suggests it wasn’t all business.

item.title: Fred Segal Has a New Owner. This Time It’s Aritzia.
item.content:encoded: The storied Los Angeles retailer, once recognized as an arbiter of West Coast style, has been acquired by the mass-market brand Aritzia.

item.title: After Supreme Court Loss, Trump Plans to Impose Global Tariffs Using Different Laws
item.content:encoded: The administration has been preparing for months for the possibility that the Supreme Court would rule against the president and developed contingency plans.

item.title: Ask The Morning: The Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
item.content:encoded: The justices struck down a central piece of President Trump’s agenda. What does that mean?

item.title: Supreme Court Tariff Ruling to Spur Chaotic Refund Process
item.content:encoded: The Trump administration says it could take years and additional litigation for importers to get their money back.

item.title: Tariff Whiplash Clouds Outlook for Federal Budget
item.content:encoded: The tariffs thrown out by the Supreme Court had become an important revenue source. President Trump said he could replace that money with other levies.

item.title: Christopher S. Wren, Times Bureau Chief in Hostile Lands, Dies at 89
item.content:encoded: Over three decades, he reported from Moscow, Beijing, Tehran and elsewhere and wrote well-received books based on his reporting, including one about his globe-trotting cat.

item.title: Supreme Court Justices Strike Down Trump’s Tariffs
item.content:encoded: President Trump was the first to invoke the International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977 to set tariffs on imported goods from more than 100 countries.

item.title: A Cancer Detection Test Fails in Major Study
item.content:encoded: A closely watched clinical trial in Britain that screened blood for early detection of cancer did not show a reduction in diagnoses at later stages of the disease.

item.title: Some Reese’s Treats Drop the Milk Chocolate. Mr. Reese Disapproves.
item.content:encoded: With cocoa prices high, Hershey’s has changed some of its candy recipes. The grandson of the man who invented the original Peanut Butter Cup said he was “embarrassed.”

item.title: Why the United States Is Seeing an Ongoing Tourism Slump
item.content:encoded: Last year, the U.S. was the only major destination to see a decline in international travelers. With increased scrutiny at the border, ICE violence and unpredictable policies, the new year isn’t looking better.

item.title: Trump and Indonesia Sign Trade Deal, Locking In 19% Tariffs
item.content:encoded: The countries made official an agreement reached last year, with Indonesia avoiding a higher tariff and committing to cooperate on export controls.

item.title: U.S. Economy Grew Modestly at End of 2025
item.content:encoded: Gross domestic product expanded at a 1.4 percent annual rate in the last quarter of the year, hit by the effects of the government shutdown.

item.title: Can an A.I. Productivity Boom Clear a Path for More Rate Cuts? Trump’s Fed Pick Thinks So.
item.content:encoded: As Federal Reserve chair, Kevin M. Warsh may face a tough task persuading his colleagues to lower borrowing costs because of potential productivity gains.

item.title: Is Blue Owl Private Credit’s ‘Canary in the Coal Mine’?
item.content:encoded: Steep declines in the shares of private lenders, after a major fund changed how investors can withdraw money, have sparked worries about more trouble to come.

item.title: Blue Owl Capital Sets Off New Fears About the Private Credit Industry
item.content:encoded: The lender’s announcement that investors will no longer be able to ask for a set amount of money back from its funds prompted worries about the private credit industry.

item.title: Trump Administration Uses ‘Equal Time’ Rule to Reshape Late-Night TV
item.content:encoded: The F.C.C. is using the “equal time” provision to take aim at hosts like Stephen Colbert. The impact could reshape how talk shows handle politics.

item.title: Labor Secretary’s Husband Barred From Department Premises After Reports of Sexual Assaults
item.content:encoded: At least two female staff members said Dr. Shawn DeRemer had touched them inappropriately at the agency in Washington.

item.title: Bill Gates Cancels Speech in India Amid Epstein Controversy
item.content:encoded: The philanthropist made the announcement on Thursday, after having earlier confirmed his participation in a prominent artificial intelligence summit in India.

item.title: Doing Your Taxes? We Want to Hear From You.
item.content:encoded: The New York Times is looking to speak to Americans about how the most recent tax cuts are affecting their pocketbooks.
